articles.title: CORPORATE STRUCTURE
articles.summary: This document outlines the corporate structure of the San Jose Amateur Astronomers. It establishes the organization as a non-profit corporation dedicated to astronomy and allied sciences through research and education, with its principal office located in Santa Clara County, California.

articles.title: MEMBERS
articles.summary: This document outlines the three classes of membership for the San Jose Amateur Astronomers corporation: Active, Contributing, and Honorary Members. It details the qualifications, privileges (such as voting rights and a 'Sky & Telescope' subscription for Active and Contributing Members), and the process for conferring each type of membership, particularly by the Board of Directors.

articles.title: Page 2
articles.summary: This document outlines the specific rights and privileges of honorary members within an organization. Honorary members are granted all the rights of active members, with the key exceptions of not being allowed to vote or to receive the "Sky & Telescope" magazine.

articles.title: SECTION 2. DUES.
articles.summary: This document outlines the policy for annual membership dues, establishing a fiscal year from July 1 to June 30. The Board of Directors determines the amount and payment deadline for annual dues, with new member dues prorated unless joining in the last quarter, in which case the forthcoming year's dues are also charged. Membership includes a subscription to "Sky & Telescope," though additional household members pay a reduced rate without the magazine.

articles.title: SECTION 1. PLACE OF MEETINGS:
articles.summary: This section outlines that membership meetings will take place monthly, with the specific time and location to be determined by the Board of Directors. It establishes a standing requirement for regular member gatherings under the board's discretion.

articles.title: SECTION 2. ANNUAL MEETINGS:
articles.summary: This document designates the regular June monthly meeting as the Annual Meeting. During this meeting, Directors of the corporation are to be elected, with nominations accepted from both a dedicated committee and from the floor. A quorum of twenty-five percent of the active membership is required for this specific meeting.

articles.title: SECTION 3. SPECIAL MEETINGS:
articles.summary: This section outlines the process for convening special meetings of the organization's membership. Such meetings can be initiated either by an order from the President or through a demand made by a majority of the Board of Directors.

articles.title: SECTION 4. NOTICES OF MEETINGS:
articles.summary: This document outlines the notification requirements for different types of organizational meetings. Active members must receive at least five days' written notice for Special and Annual Meetings. Notice for regular meetings is only mandatory when there is a change in the meeting's time or place.

articles.title: SECTION 5. QUORUM AT MEMBERSHIP MEETINGS:
articles.summary: This document outlines the quorum requirements for membership meetings, excluding annual meetings. It states that the active members attending such meetings will constitute a quorum, and a simple majority vote of those present is sufficient to conduct business.

articles.title: DIRECTORS
articles.summary: This document outlines the structure, powers, and operational procedures for the Board of Directors. It details that the nine-member board, composed of active corporation members, is responsible for managing corporate affairs, with directors serving two-year staggered terms. The text also specifies rules for filling vacancies, conducting meetings (regular and special), quorum requirements, and qualifications for board membership, including attendance stipulations.

articles.title: OFFICERS
articles.summary: This document outlines the roles, selection process, and duties of the Corporation's officers: President, Vice President, Secretary, and Treasurer. Officers are chosen by the Board of Directors from its membership for one-year terms, with a special provision for electing general members to an office if necessary. It details the specific responsibilities and powers assigned to the President, Vice President, and Secretary.

articles.title: SECTION 5. DUTIES OF THE TREASURER:
articles.summary: This document outlines the specific duties of the Treasurer for a Corporation. These responsibilities primarily involve being the custodian of corporate books and papers, supervising financial accounts, managing corporate funds and securities, and handling all receipts and disbursements. The Treasurer is also responsible for depositing monies, disbursing funds as ordered by the Board, and rendering financial reports to the President and Board of Directors.

articles.title: SECTION 6. VACANCIES:
articles.summary: This section outlines the process for filling vacancies in corporate offices. When a vacancy occurs, the Board of Directors is responsible for electing a successor to serve the remainder of the unexpired term.

articles.title: COMMITTEES
articles.summary: The document outlines the structure and duties of two types of committees. It details the Nominating Committee, which is appointed by the President one month prior to the Annual Meeting to propose candidates for director elections. Additionally, it states that the Board of Directors has the discretion to establish other committees, controlling their powers and terms of service.

articles.title: DISSOLUTION
articles.summary: This document outlines the procedure for the dissolution of a corporation, stating that it requires a three-fourths vote of active members present at a regular meeting. Upon dissolution, the distribution of funds and properties will be determined by a majority vote of the Board of Directors, pending approval from active members.

articles.title: Article 7, Section 1 Cont.
articles.summary: This excerpt continues Article 7, Section 1 of an unspecified document, outlining a restriction. It states that certain materials or information shall not be distributed to members if such distribution is unlawful.

articles.title: ARTICLE 8
articles.summary: Article 8 outlines the procedures for amending or repealing the By-Laws, requiring a two-thirds vote of active members at an annual or special meeting. All active members must receive notice of proposed changes, which must also be read at a regular meeting before being considered. The original By-Laws were adopted in 1958, with the first amendments made on September 5, 1975.
